Légation des Etats Unis au Département
Bruxelles, le 9 Janvier 1888.
Monsieur,

A la suite d'instructions reçuis de mon Gouvernement, j'ai l'honneur d'attirer votre attention sur le second articlee du décret du Roi- Souverain de l'Etat Indépendant du Congo, sur l'usage des pavillons, décret en date du 30 avril 1889 et publie au No 5 du Bulletin (Mai -1887).

D'après l'interprétation à donner à cet article, il est prescrit à tout bâtiment prive navignant dans les sous de l'Etat
Indépendat du Congo en amont des de Léopoldville, d'arboreur, á l'arrière, le pavillon de l'Etat. S'il possède des papiers du établissant sa nationalité étrander, il pourra arborer, en outre, la pavillon de son pays.

D'après la second article de l'Acte Général de la Conféreence de Berlin, tous les pavillolns, sans distinction de nationalité, out libre accès á toutes les du Congo et de ses affluents, y compris les lacs, ainsi qu'a tous les canaux qui pourraient être excusés à l'avenir dans le but de entre eux les cours d'eau ou les lacs compris dans toute l'entendue des territoires décrits à l'article de cet Si le Gouvernement des
Etats-Unis n'a pas été partie contractante á cet Acte, il n'en partage pas moins, pour ses vaisseaux et pour ses citoyens, la paisible jouissance des avantages accordés par l'Etat Indépendant du Congo á tout le monde en général.

Le commerce de l'Etat Indépendant du Congo étant donc entiérement libre, le navire américaine envisage comme véhicle de transit peut être ou un vaisseau enregistre de la marine marchande des Etats-Unis, ou un bâtiment non enregistré appartenant á des citoyens des Etats-Unis, sans que cette distinction puisse porter atteinte, j'insiste sur ce point, á la jouissance du privilige de navigation qui avais est garanté
Dans l'un comme dans l'autre cas, il a le droit d'arborer le pavillon des Etats-Unis.

Mon Gouvernement maintient, comme un principe de droit international reconnu, que les navires ont non seulement du faculté d'arborer, n'importe où ils se rendent, le pavillon du pays dont ses propriétaites sont sujets, mais qu'en général c'est un devoir pour eux d'arborer ce pavillon.

Ce principe serait toutefois directement combatter par une disposition que obligerait les vaisseau navignant dans les eaux d'un Etat particulier á arborer le pavillon de cet Etat, quand ces eaux sont ouvertes, comme c'est le cas ici, á la navigation étangére.
C'est bien la le
sens qui parait devoir être a donné á l'article 2 du décret royal du 30 avril 1887.

Cet article a pour effet de substituer le pavillon de l'Etat Indépendant du Congo au pavillon national á du vaisseau en obligeant celui-ci á arborer à l'arrière le pavillon du Congo; il est évident que les pavillons de deux nations ne peuvent être tous deux déployés en même temps á la même hampe. Ce déploiement dénoterait, en certaines circonstances du moins, que le navire est en prise par la nationalité dont les conteurs sont placées le plus hout.
Je pense que c'est un usage universel que le pavillon arboré á l'arrière est celui de la nationalité du navire.

La dernière clause de l'article 2 du décret du
30 avril regarde comme un droit de la part des autorités de l'Etat du Congo de déterminer á quelles conditions les navires peuvent arborer leur pavillon national, ces conditions étant subordonnées á la possession des papiers de bord établissant la nationalité des bâtiments.

Mon Gouvernement soutient qu'il appartient á chaque pays de déterminer pour lui même les conditions de l'usage des pavillons á bord de ses navires. La régle des Etats-Unis est que les vaisseaux bona fide appartenant á des citoyens de ce pays ont le droit, lorsqu'ils sont á l'étranger, d'arborer le pavillon des Etats-Unis quels que soient les papiers qu'ils possédent.

Je suis en conséquence chargé par mon Gouvernement
de protester contre l'application de l'article 2 de décret du 30 avril 1887 aux navires appartenant á des citoyens des Etats-Unis:
1) en ce qu'il oblige ces vaisseaux á arborer á l'arriére de pavillon de l'Etat Indépendant du Congo. Le droit d'arborer un autre pavillon que celui de leur propre nationalité n'est pas reconnu;
2) en ce que le droit d'enforcer leur pavillon national est subordonné á la possession de papiers de bord établissant leur nationalité.

Legation of the United States of America
Brussels January 9, 1888.
Sir:

Under instructions from my Government, I have the honor to invite your attention to the second article of the decree of His Majesty, the Sovereign of the Independent State of the Congo, on the subject of the use of flags bearing date the 30th of April 1887, and published in the Official Bulletin No 5 (May 1887).

As this article is understood, it decrees that every private vessel navigating the waters of the Independent State of the Congo, up the Stream beyond the falls of Leopoldville, will be required to hoist, at the Stern, the flag of the
To Mr. Edmund Van Eetvelde General Administrator of the Department of Foreign Affairs.
the State, and that if the vessel possesses Ships papers establishing the nationality. She may, in addition, fly the flag of her country.

By the second article of the General act pf the Berlin Conference, all flags without distinction of nationality, are secured in the right to have free access to all the waters of the Congo and its a affluents, including the lakes, and to all the canals that in the future may be cut, with the object of uniting the watercourses or the lakes confined in the whole extend of the territories described in Article I. of that instrument, and while the Government of the United States is not a party to that convention, yet the peaceful use of the benefits offered by the Congo Free
Free State to the World at large, are shared by their vessels and their citizens.

The Commerce of the Congo Free State being thus freely opened, the American vessel viewed as vehicle of transit, may be either a registered vessel of the Merchant Marine of the United States or an unregistered vessel owned by citizens of the United States, without effecting, it is insisted her enjoyment of the guaranteed privilege of navigation. In either case, she has the right to fly the flag of the United States.

My Government hold it to be a settled principle of international law that
that Ships not only are entitled to carry wherever they go, the flag of the country of which their owners are citizens, but that it is their duty, as a rule, to carry such flag.

The principle stated however, would be directly antagonized by a rule that vessels navigating the rivers of a particular State, when such rivers are open, as in this case, to foreign navigation, should carry the flag of that State.
This appears to the purport of article 2. of the royal decree of the 30th of April 1887.

Its effect is to substitute the flag of
of the Congo Free State for the National flag of the vessel, by requiring the flag of the State to be displayed at the stern, as it is evident that the flags of the two nations could not both fly at the same staff, or from the same gaff. To do this would be, under some circumstances at least, to denote that the vessel was a prize to the nationality whose colors were uppermost.
I understand it to be the Universal usage that the flag carried on a gaff or at the flagstaff at the stern is the flag of the vessels nationality.

The lase clause of Article 2. of the
the decree of April 30th implies the assertion of a right on the part of the authorities of the Congo State to determine the sufficiency of the vessels' title to fly her national flag, by making it depend on the possession of papers establishing her nationality.

It is maintained by my Government that it is the province of each country to determine for itself the conditions for the use of its flag upon its vessels, and the United States rule is that vessels bona fide owned by the citizens of the United States, are entitled when abroad, to carry the flag of the United States, irrespective of the question of the papers
papers they may have on board.
I am therefore instructed by my Government to protest against the application of Article 2. of the royal decree of April 30, 1887 to vessels owned by citizens of the United States:

1st In requiring such vessels to fly the flag of the Independent State of the Congo, at the stern. The right to require such vessels to hoist the flag of any other nationality than their own, is denied.
2nd In making the right to carry a national flag on such vessels dependent upon the possession of papers on board establishing nationality.
I avail myself of the opportunity to renew to you Sir, the assurances of my most distinguished consideration.
Lambert Tree

Brussels, January 9th 1888.
Mister,

According to the interpretation to give to this article, it is prescribed to all private boats navigating in the waters of the Independent

In the one as in the other case, he has the right to display the flag of the United States.

My government maintains, as a principal of recognized international right, that the vessels have not only the faculty to display, wherever they render themselves, the flag of the country where its owners are subjects, but that in general it is a duty for them to display this flag.

This principal will be nevertheless directly combated by a disposition that would oblige the vessels navigating in the waters of a particular state to display the flag of this state, when these waters are open, as it is the case here, to the foreign navigation.

It is there the
sense that appears to have to be given to the article 2 of the royal decree of April 30th 1887.

This article has for effect of substituting the flag of the Independent State of the Congo to the national flag of the vessel in obliging this one to display at the back the flag of the Congo; it is evident that the flags of two nations can not both be deployed at the same time on the same pole. This deployment would denote, in certain circumstances at least, that the vessel is taken by the nationality which the narrators are placed the highest.
I think that it is a universal use that the flag displayed at the back is that of the nationality of the vessel.

The last clause of the article 2 of the decree from the
30th of April looks as a right of the part of the authorities of the state of the Congo to determine in which conditions the vessels can display their national flag, these conditions being subordinated to the possession of the vessel papers establishing the nationality of the boats.

My government supports that it belongs to each country to determine for itself the conditions of the use of flags aboard its vessels. The rule of the United States is that the vessels of good faith belonging to the citizens of this country have the right, while they are abroad, to display the flag of the United States some being the papers that they possess.

I am in consequence charged by my Government
to protest against the application of the article 2 of the decree from the 30th of April 1887 to the vessels belonging to the citizens of the United States:

1) in that which it obliges these vessels to display at the back the flag of the Independent State of the Congo. The right to display another flag than that of their own nationality is not recognized;
2) in that which the right to enforce their national flag is subordinated to the possession of the vessels papers establishing their nationality.
